importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the lawsuit filing and the key event in the political dispute between Arizona and Speaker Mike Johnson.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from late September to October 2025, during which Adelita Grijalva won the election and the subsequent delay in swearing-in occurred.

keyTakeAways: The U.S. House Speaker Mike Johnson refused to administer the oath of office to newly elected Arizona Congresswoman Adelita Grijalva due to the ongoing government shutdown, claiming it follows precedent set by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, filed a lawsuit arguing that the Constitution requires elected members to be sworn in upon election and that no such authority exists for the Speaker to unilaterally delay the swearing-in process.
The lawsuit claims Johnson’s refusal is politically motivated, aimed at delaying a petition to release Jeffrey Epstein-related records and to strengthen his position in budget negotiations.
The Constitution does not specify who must administer the oath, only that it must be taken by a qualified individual, and Johnson has not provided any valid reason for inability to administer it.
Grijalva has not spoken to Johnson since winning her election and is attempting to schedule a meeting to resolve the standoff.
The lawsuit seeks a court order allowing a qualified individual to administer the oath to Grijalva if Johnson refuses.

namedEntities.name: Adelita Grijalva
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Newly elected member of Congress from Arizona
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the central figure in the legal dispute, representing the elected member whose oath is being blocked by the House Speaker.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the key decision-maker who refused to administer the oath to Grijalva, citing precedent and political strategy.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She filed the lawsuit challenging the Speaker’s refusal to seat Grijalva, asserting constitutional rights of newly elected officials.

namedEntities.name: Nancy Pelosi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Johnson cites her precedent of delaying swearing-in during recess, which forms the basis of his argument and the point of contention in the legal claim.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Epstein
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Controversial figure linked to a petition for record releases
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is intended to prevent a vote on releasing Epstein-related records, indicating a political motive.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central institution where the constitutional dispute over the swearing-in of members occurs.

namedEntities.name: Capitol Hill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Physical location of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Where the political decisions and public statements related to the oath refusal were made.

namedEntities.name: Arizona
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The state whose elected representative is being denied office, leading to the state's legal action against the federal House.

namedEntities.name: Washington, D.C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Where the lawsuit was filed in federal court, indicating the legal venue of the dispute.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to administer the oath of office to newly elected Arizona congresswoman Adelita Grijalva, who won her seat in late September 2025. Johnson claims he is following the precedent set by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, delaying swearing-in until the House returns from recess. However, the lawsuit argues that the U.S. Constitution does not grant the Speaker the authority to block the swearing-in of a duly elected member, especially when no valid reason is given. The lawsuit further alleges that Johnson’s delay is politically motivated—aimed at blocking a petition to release Jeffrey Epstein-related records and to strengthen his position in budget negotiations. The case underscores a constitutional question about the role of the Speaker in seating newly elected members and the balance between political discretion and constitutional obligations. Grijalva has not spoken to Johnson since her election and is attempting to meet with him to resolve the impasse.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear In Democrats’ Newest Congresswoman
